Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: Got a request to attend court to provide testimony when required.
Story: I stared at the calendar, my heart pounding. The family ceremony was tomorrow—my mother’s voice still echoed in my mind, reminding me how important it was for me to lead the ritual this year. “You’re the eldest now,” she’d said, her eyes shining with pride and hope. I knew how much it meant to her, to all of us, to keep our traditions alive. But then my phone buzzed: a message from the precinct. The court date for the case I’d been working on had been moved up. I was required to testify, no exceptions. As a police officer, I was expected to act with integrity, to be there when justice called, no matter what. I felt torn in two—my family needed me to honor our heritage, but my duty demanded I stand for the truth in court. The weight of both worlds pressed on my chest, and I wondered how I could possibly choose between them.
